b7f5eef746e6.title: On this cold and snowy February morning, I was spirited away to your kitchen and the work and the…

paragraphs.text:
On this cold and snowy February morning, I was spirited away to your kitchen and the work and the smells and the butter soaking into a warm slice.
This makes me want to get out my bread books or search the internet for something that has a tough crust and an inside full of air pockets.
Thanks for the sensory treat as well as your comments about this…

850daf5f1600.title: Your story gave me the warm bread feeling you described.

paragraphs.text: Your story gave me the warm bread feeling you described. I feel toasty, satisfied, and peaceful — and inspired. My grandchildren and I started cooking together in the fall of 2015, but lost our team momentum and barely cooked in 2016. They’ve been asking to resume our culinary adventures. I think bread must be added to our next menu.
paragraphs.name: 5e78

paragraphs.text: Really loved that one. Expertly written and clever weaving of emotions/psyche/self into the process of bread making. It was a pleasure to read. Thank you.

942f14fbec0b.title: Late last year I finally got over my fear of bread and jumped in with sourdough.

paragraphs.text: Late last year I finally got over my fear of bread and jumped in with sourdough. Using the recipe from The Kitchn, I brought loaf after loaf of old world goodness to life. It made me proud of myself. Creation that served a purpose, one that you could consume. Bread is magic. Keep baking, my friend.
paragraphs.name: f762

paragraphs.text: Perfect Post, thanks.

6ad97279a17f.title: Cor, this has a lot of movements.

paragraphs.text: Cor, this has a lot of movements. It’s like a breezy day, blowing smells across me and skittering leaves around me. And sometimes I find refuge with tea and a window and a kitchen to stand in. A quiet moment, even though the moving things move on.
paragraphs.name: 2de0

content.subtitle: I have this theory that because bread is global and historic, one of the first things we learned to make, it is enthroned within the most…

virtuals.subtitle: I have this theory that because bread is global and historic, one of the first things we learned to make, it is enthroned within the most…

paragraphs.text: Bread of Life
paragraphs.name: f519

paragraphs.text: I have this theory that because bread is global and historic, one of the first things we learned to make, it is enthroned within the most primitive parts of our modern brains. No matter where we are from, no matter our social status, our job, our family or friends…the smell of warm bread, just out of the oven…
paragraphs.name: b05f

b51bba358073.title: Reading this fed my need to knead. Thank you.

content.subtitle: God help me, I have a few fancy mixers 😳

virtuals.subtitle: God help me, I have a few fancy mixers 😳

paragraphs.text: I’m a Pullman loaf purist. I also love bread crust so my loaves are always in my Pullman pans, lids pulled tightly. I fill them just a bit too much so they strain against the lid, making that all around crust just a little deeper into the bread and forcing the loaves to be as square as possible. Perfect toast, perfect French toast on day two!
paragraphs.name: b922

paragraphs.text: God help me, I have a few fancy mixers 😳
paragraphs.name: ae42

paragraphs.text: Lovely writing. I know that chest feeling too. Bread making works to sooth it for me too. My starter is two years old this week. I feel like I should throw him a party. Well, yes, it is a him, as you ask. His name is Alfreddo and he’s a fridge dwelling rye starter. Endlessly patient and flexible. I’m going to give him the week off after reading this…
paragraphs.name: 56ac

paragraphs.text: The thing about bread-making that elevates it above all else in the kitchen is that it’s alive. Literally bursting and popping with life. You can watch it as it rises, hear it if you bend near. You are, with your life-worn hands, shaping life into artful sustenance, as the earliest hands once did. Massaging tiny beasties into a sustaining thing. This sounds like what needs to happen in my middle, a cycle of creation and consumption to fuel something sane and reliable. Maybe this is why they call the middle ‘the breadbasket’ (though I suspect that’s a little lower, in the stomach, where the bread goes).

Worry is where I begin with the challah, fresh on the heels of the rustic flop. I’m back to Deb at Smitten, as she was so kind to me with that lovely Sally Lunn. Her challah looks gorgeous (of course, marketing, when will I learn) and she doesn’t seem daunted, so I tentatively dive.
paragraphs.name: 12b7
